text.tspan: Hey wait... what if we took the way we
computed expected values for state families,
That is, how about we let the expected value
of an infinite matrix product state be equal
not to a value but to a function, like f(N)=3N
or f(N)=N^2. In fact, this fundamentally
makes more sense than assigning a value to
an infinite expectation because we usually
describe expectation values in terms of, say,
energy per site, which is exactly saying that
the energy is equal to f(N)=EN where E is the
Furthermore, if we let M = S^*OS be the
result of contracting the state and operator
tensors, then in principle we can compute
M^N in closed form by taking advantage of
the Jordan Normal Form, which gives us,
